title: Some of These Days
text:
"Some of These Days" is a <a href="popular%20music">popular</a> <a href="song">song</a>, written and composed by <a href="Shelton%20Brooks">Shelton Brooks</a>, published in <a href="1910%20in%20music">1910</a>, and associated with the performer <a href="Sophie%20Tucker">Sophie Tucker</a>.
Background.
Shelton Brooks and "Some of These Days" was brought to Sophie Tucker's attention in 1910 by her maid, who insisted she meet Brooks and hear the song. Tucker instantly recognized its hit potential, performed and recorded many versions throughout the years, and eventually it became her signature song—including landing movie appearances to perform it.
Tucker first recorded the song along with others on wax cylinder format in 1910–11. In 1926, on 78 RPM record format and backed by Ted Lewis and his band, Tucker recorded her classic, million-selling 1926 version, which stayed in the #1 position on the charts for five weeks beginning November 23, 1926, and re-affirmed her lasting association with the song.
"Some of These Days" has been recorded by many other artists, including <a href="Ethel%20Waters">Ethel Waters</a>, <a href="Louis%20Armstrong">Louis Armstrong</a>, Coco Briaval, <a href="Elkie%20Brooks">Elkie Brooks</a>, <a href="Cab%20Calloway">Cab Calloway</a>, <a href="Bing%20Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>, <a href="Bobby%20Darin">Bobby Darin</a>, <a href="Ella%20Fitzgerald">Ella Fitzgerald</a>, <a href="Diahann%20Carroll">Diahann Carroll</a>, <a href="Danny%20Aiello">Danny Aiello</a>, <a href="Judy%20Garland">Judy Garland</a>, Matt Forbes, <a href="The%20Hot%20Sardines">The Hot Sardines</a>, <a href="Susan%20Maughan">Susan Maughan</a>, <a href="The%20McGuire%20Sisters">The McGuire Sisters</a>, the <a href="Original%20Dixieland%20Jass%20Band">Original Dixieland Jass Band</a>, <a href="Sue%20Raney">Sue Raney</a>, <a href="Serena%20Ryder">Serena Ryder</a>, <a href="Sidney%20Bechet">Sidney Bechet</a>, <a href="Leon%20Redbone">Leon Redbone</a>, and recently by Erica Lewis with the band <a href="Tuba%20Skinny">Tuba Skinny</a>.
Appearances in film.
"Some of These Days" made the first of many movie soundtrack appearances in "<a href="Lights%20of%20New%20York%20%281928%20film%29">Lights of New York</a>" (1928), the first "all talking" motion picture, being one of several songs played by the house band of the nightclub where the film is set. Sophie Tucker herself sang "Some of These Days" in character as a <a href="nightclub%20singer">nightclub singer</a> in the 1929 film "<a href="Honky%20Tonk%20%281929%20film%29">Honky Tonk</a>" with reprise performances (as herself) in "<a href="Broadway%20Melody%20of%201938">Broadway Melody of 1938</a>" and "<a href="Follow%20the%20Boys">Follow the Boys</a>" (1944).
Other films to feature the song include "<a href="Scarface%20%281932%20film%29">Scarface</a>" and "<a href="Three%20on%20a%20Match">Three on a Match</a>" (both 1932), both featuring actress <a href="Ann%20Dvorak">Ann Dvorak</a> dancing to the song: in "Scarface" the song is played in a nightclub by <a href="Gus%20Arnheim">Gus Arnheim</a>'s band while in "Three on a Match" Dvorak dances while actor Harry Seymour plays "Some of These Days" on a piano.
In "<a href="Rose%20Marie%20%281936%20film%29">Rose-Marie</a>" (1936), <a href="Jeanette%20MacDonald">Jeanette MacDonald</a> attempts a lyric soprano rendition in a <a href="Klondike%2C%20Yukon">Klondike</a> café whose regular vocalist (<a href="Gilda%20Gray">Gilda Gray</a>) upstages McDonald with an earthy performance of the song. "Some of These Days" was also featured in the 1939 release "<a href="Only%20Angels%20Have%20Wings">Only Angels Have Wings</a>" in which <a href="Jean%20Arthur">Jean Arthur</a> plays the song on the piano in a <a href="cantina">cantina</a>.
